title: Why People Hurt Each Other and How to Avoid It
content:
### Why People Hurt Each Other and How to Avoid It

In a world filled with words, gestures, and unspoken expectations, one question echoes through our relationships and interactions: **Why do people hurt each other?** Whether it‚Äôs between teacher and student, husband and wife, senior and junior, or even strangers online‚Äîhurt seems to be an inevitable part of human connection. But is it truly unavoidable? And if not, how can we navigate life without inflicting‚Äîor receiving‚Äîso much pain?

---

## üé≠ The Nature of Hurt: Why We Harm One Another

At its core, hurt arises from **resistance**‚Äîthe friction between what we expect and what we receive, between who we think we are and how the world treats us.

> ‚ÄúHurt means resistance. If you shoot a bullet at a wall, it leaves a hole. That hole is resistance. The wall tried to stop the bullet from passing through‚Äîso it got hurt.‚Äù

We hurt others‚Äîand get hurt‚Äîbecause we are attached to identities, desires, and expectations. The ego, like a rigid wall, wants to preserve itself. It resists change, criticism, and rejection. And in that resistance, pain is born.

### The Two Sources of Hurt:

1. **Unconscious Hurting**: Most of the time, we hurt others without even realizing it. Our actions, words, and gestures arise from our own unresolved inner turmoil.
2. **Intentional Hurting**: Sometimes, we hurt others knowingly‚Äîdriven by ego, desire, or the need to protect our self-image.

But in both cases, the root is the same: **we are not empty**. We are full of ourselves‚Äîour wants, our fears, our stories.

---

## üéØ The Illusion of ‚ÄúI Love You‚Äù: When Affection Becomes a Transaction

One of the most revealing examples of how we unknowingly hurt each other lies in our expressions of love and affection.

> ‚ÄúWhen you say ‚ÄòI love you,‚Äô you look deeply into the other person‚Äôs eyes‚Äîjust like a hunter looks at its prey.‚Äù

We say ‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù but often, it‚Äôs not a gift‚Äîit‚Äôs a proposal. We are waiting for something in return: validation, attention, affection, or security. We refresh our messages, stay up all night waiting for a reply, and when it doesn‚Äôt come, we say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hurt.‚Äù

But were you really giving love? Or were you shooting an arrow, hoping to bring back a prize?

### How to Respond When Someone Says ‚ÄúI Love You‚Äù:

- **Ask clearly**: ‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù
- **Be honest**: If you can‚Äôt be selfless, at least be transparent.
- **Avoid hidden expectations**: Unexpressed hopes are future wounds waiting to happen.

---

## üß± The Wall vs. The Sky: Two Ways of Being

Imagine two objects: a **wall** and the **sky**.

- The **wall** is solid, defined, and resists. When a bullet hits it, it gets a hole. It is hurt.
- The **sky** is empty, open, and offers no resistance. A bullet passes through it without leaving a mark. It is unhurt.

We are hurt because we have become walls. We have built identities, desires, and attachments. We want to preserve ourselves. But the more solid we become, the more we can be broken.

### How to Become Like the Sky:

- **Practice emptiness**: Don‚Äôt let opinions, praise, or insults stick to you.
- **Let go of self-image**: The more you define yourself, the more you can be hurt.
- **Stop preserving the ego**: The ego is rigid. Consciousness is fluid.

> ‚ÄúIf you become like the sky, then even if someone shoots at you, there‚Äôs no one there to receive the hurt.‚Äù

---

## üíî The Cycle of Hurt: How We Invite Pain

We often complain, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been hurt,‚Äù but we rarely ask: **Why did I make myself available to be hurt?**

> ‚ÄúYou say ‚ÄòI love you‚Äô not as a gift, but as an investment. And when the returns don‚Äôt come, you cry.‚Äù

We accept respect, validation, and love from the world‚Äîand then we‚Äôre shocked when the same world insults us or takes them back. But why did we take them in the first place?

We feel incomplete, so we grasp at external things to fill the void. And the moment we take something, we become slaves to the giver.

### The Trap of ‚ÄúI Need You‚Äù:

- We seek love, respect, or validation to feel whole.
- The giver now has power over us.
- If we don‚Äôt meet their expectations, they withdraw what they gave‚Äîand we feel hurt.

The solution is not to stop receiving, but to **receive only from those who give selflessly**‚Äîor to enter into clear, honest transactions where expectations are stated upfront.

---

## üìú A Practical Guide to Avoiding Hurt

### 1. Be Clear About Your Expectations
If you have desires, express them openly. Don‚Äôt hide your hopes and then feel betrayed when they‚Äôre not met.

> ‚ÄúEither have no expectations, or express them clearly. Don‚Äôt play hide and seek with your own heart.‚Äù

### 2. Don‚Äôt Build Solid Identities
The more you define yourself‚Äî‚ÄúI am respectable,‚Äù ‚ÄúI am successful,‚Äù ‚ÄúI am loved‚Äù‚Äîthe more you can be hurt when those labels are challenged.

### 3. Stop Taking Things Personally
When someone insults you, ask: **Who is being insulted?** If there‚Äôs no solid ‚Äúyou,‚Äù then there‚Äôs no one to receive the insult.

### 4. Embrace Detachment
Detachment is not coldness‚Äîit‚Äôs freedom. It‚Äôs the ability to engage fully without being owned by the outcome.

### 5. Don‚Äôt Get Attached to Praise or Blame
If you accept praise, you must also accept criticism. If you want the world‚Äôs respect, you must also be ready for its disrespect.

> ‚ÄúIf you accept one, you must accept the other. So why accept either?‚Äù

---

## üå± The Fear of Selflessness: ‚ÄúWhat If I Get Exploited?‚Äù

A common fear arises: ‚ÄúIf I become selfless, won‚Äôt people take advantage of me?‚Äù

This question itself is a trick of the ego‚Äîa way to avoid the responsibility of gratitude and openness.

> ‚ÄúAll assumptions are conspiracies. They are designed to protect the ego, not to discover the truth.‚Äù

We imagine future problems to avoid present transformation. But the truth is:

- When you change, your world changes with you.
- You won‚Äôt be the same person in a new situation‚Äîyou‚Äôll be the version of yourself that fits that reality.

---

## üîÅ The Pendulum of Detachment

Many worry: ‚ÄúIf I detach, won‚Äôt I lose all motivation? How will I function in the world?‚Äù

But detachment is not indifference. It‚Äôs not a pendulum swinging between extremes‚Äîit‚Äôs the **center** from which the pendulum moves.

> ‚ÄúYou are still attached to the center. That‚Äôs why you return. Real detachment is not moving away from life‚Äîit‚Äôs engaging from a place of freedom.‚Äù

You can study, work, love, and live‚Äîwithout being owned by the results.

---

## üí¨ Final Words: The Art of Living Without Hurt

Hurt is not inevitable. It is the result of a false relationship with ourselves and the world.

We hurt because we are full.
We get hurt because we resist.

The way out is to become empty‚Äîlike the sky.
To engage without grasping.
To love without demanding.
To live without preserving.

> ‚ÄúLet there be nobody here to receive hurt.‚Äù

When there‚Äôs no one to be hurt, there is no hurt.
When there‚Äôs no one to be praised, there is no dependency.
When there‚Äôs no one to be protected, there is no fear.

This is not a philosophy‚Äîit‚Äôs a way of being.
And it begins with a single step: **stop building walls, and start becoming the sky.**
